Title: A Church in transition: The intriguing use of the pallium in Tudor England
Abstract: © Cambridge University Press 2017.What was the source of authority in the Church in Tudor England? This article traces the use of an ancient symbol of the power of metropolitan archbishops, the woollen pallium, between 1533 and 1603. The later Henrician Church saw this garment as a sign of royal supremacy. Under Mary, however, Archbishop Pole made extravagant claims which led the Elizabethan Church to reject earlier Tudor notions ofthis symbol. Set against the backdropofthe source of episcopal jurisdiction, this article traces the use ofthe pallium in England in a Church moving from Roman obedience to a Protestant settlement.
